title: An individual-specific understanding of how synchrony becomes curative
descriptions:
The proposed project, titled "An individual-specific understanding of how synchrony becomes curative," seeks to challenge the conventional assumption that higher levels of interpersonal synchrony always lead to better mental health outcomes. The project, SynSig, aims to investigate individual-specific synchrony signatures, explore tailored corrections to these signatures, and analyze how relationships can be transformed into curative ones through adjustments in synchrony. 

To achieve these objectives, the project will utilize multimodal markers such as motion, acoustic, physiological, and facial expression data. Individuals will be studied in dyadic interactions with both humans and virtual humans, allowing for a comprehensive understanding of synchrony dynamics. The project will also develop a novel multimodal feedback system to facilitate momentary corrections to synchrony signatures based on individual needs.

The expected outcomes of the project include the identification of individual-specific synchrony signatures, insights into the multi-layered nature of synchrony on an individual level, and a better understanding of how human interactions impact mental health. By drawing causal inferences between synchrony adjustments and mental health outcomes, SynSig aims to provide a personalized approach to enhancing well-being through interpersonal synchrony.
